node.contents: I'm trying to make a class that acts as a pair of ints. I want to make a getter method which returns a pair, but I'm hesitant to write as it looks weird and I want to know if it legal to do this in Java or not.

astNode.text: I'm trying to make a class that acts as a pair of ints. I want to make a getter method which returns a pair, but I'm hesitant to write as it looks weird and I want to know if it legal to do this in Java or not.

elements.contents: public class Pair { private int p1; private int p2; public Pair (int p1, int p2) { this.p1 = p1; this.p2 = p2; } public Pair getPair () { return this; } }

units.rawText: public class Pair { private int p1; private int p2; public Pair (int p1, int p2) { this.p1 = p1; this.p2 = p2; } public Pair getPair () { return this; } }

node.contents: And is this a good way to return the pair, or is there an optimal way to do so?

astNode.text: And is this a good way to return the pair, or is there an optimal way to do so?

node.contents: Given that you can only call getPair() on a pair, why would you want this? Surely you would have a method to return a pair on some other type, e.g.

astNode.text: Given that you can only call getPair() on a pair, why would you want this? Surely you would have a method to return a pair on some other type, e.g.

node.contents: Note that your name is very general (a pair of what? Oh, a pair of integers...) which suggests that perhaps it should be a generic type - although you then end up with boxing for the integer case you're interested in.

astNode.text: Note that your name is very general (a pair of what? Oh, a pair of integers...) which suggests that perhaps it should be a generic type - although you then end up with boxing for the integer case you're interested in.

node.contents: While in the past I'd have supported a class like this, I've been finding more recently that a private nested type with just a bunch of fields can actually be more useful, to simply transport a collection of disparate values within a particular class.

astNode.text: While in the past I'd have supported a class like this, I've been finding more recently that a private nested type with just a bunch of fields can actually be more useful, to simply transport a collection of disparate values within a particular class.

node.contents: The method getPair() is redundant: When you create a new Pair you will already have a reference to it; e.g.

astNode.text: The method getPair() is redundant: When you create a new Pair you will already have a reference to it; e.g.

elements.contents: Pair p1 = new Pair(3,5); Pair p2 = p1.getPair(); assert p1 == p2; // p1 and p2 refer to the same object.

comments.text: // p1 and p2 refer to the same object.

units.rawText: Pair p1 = new Pair(3,5); Pair p2 = p1.getPair(); assert p1 == p2; // p1 and p2 refer to the same object.

node.contents: Hence getPair() is of no use. Note that one legitimate use for a method to return this is when implementing the builder pattern, as it allows for more compact code; e.g.

astNode.text: Hence getPair() is of no use. Note that one legitimate use for a method to return this is when implementing the builder pattern, as it allows for more compact code; e.g.

elements.contents: public int getP1() { return this.p1; } public int getP2() { return this.p2; }

units.rawText: public int getP1() { return this.p1; } public int getP2() { return this.p2; }

node.contents: No, this is not normal at all, to return a reference to this from a getter. Seeing as if you are calling getPair() you already have a reference to it. Now, if what you are trying to do is create a factory method for getting new instances of Pair, then you might want to try something like this:

astNode.text: No, this is not normal at all, to return a reference to this from a getter. Seeing as if you are calling getPair() you already have a reference to it. Now, if what you are trying to do is create a factory method for getting new instances of Pair, then you might want to try something like this:

elements.contents: public class Pair { public static Pair createPair(int p1, int p2) { return new Pair(p1, p2); } private int p1; private int p2; public Pair (int p1, int p2) { this.p1 = p1; this.p2 = p2; } }

units.rawText: public class Pair { public static Pair createPair(int p1, int p2) { return new Pair(p1, p2); } private int p1; private int p2; public Pair (int p1, int p2) { this.p1 = p1; this.p2 = p2; } }

node.contents: But even this is a trivial addition, since it provides practically no benefit over just using the constructor to create new Pair instances.

astNode.text: But even this is a trivial addition, since it provides practically no benefit over just using the constructor to create new Pair instances.

node.contents: What you've got already won't make your Pair class any more usable - if you have a reference to a Pair object then you don't need another!

astNode.text: What you've got already won't make your Pair class any more usable - if you have a reference to a Pair object then you don't need another!

node.contents: It's perfectly ok to have two separate accessors:

astNode.text: It's perfectly ok to have two separate accessors:

elements.contents: public int getFirstInt() { return this.p1; } public int getSecondInt() { return this.p2; }
